result.execSummary:
The defendant James D. Johnston was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).
  • Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).
  • Theft-Movable Property <=$2500 [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Restitution Joint/Several with Caleb Mansfield 15CF481:
Joshua Hutkowski $2,720.37
Jeffrey Bindel $546.12
Mark Dexter $173.30
Bancroft Quick Mart $84.33

superMiscConds.notes: *Pay restitution to be paid first (pay in accordance to the restitution summary)

*Obtain GED or HSED if not already done so.
*Obtain and maintain full-time employment until restitution is paid in full and then schooling or a combination of both equaling full-time.

*No contact with Caleb Mansfield, J.G., Nickolus Slusser, Bancroft Quik Mart, Jacob Slusser, Carol Novack, Carl Novack, Joshua Hutkowski, Jeffrey Bindel, Mark Dexter, Country Sports and Paragon Farms or their residences or places of employment.

*Maintain absolute sobriety with regards to alcohol or illegal drugs. 
*Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription. 
*Comply with any assessments, treatment, and programming as deemed appropriate by the Compass Assessment and the Department of Corrections.
*Provide DNA sample if not already done so  
*Not eligible for Challenge or Substance Abuse Program.

If Defendant is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.
*Pay all court ordered financial obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

(Re-sentencing hearing) Defendant James D. Johnston in court with attorney Ryan Drengler. Defendant James D. Johnston in custody. Daniel R. Hess appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
11:02 a.m. ADA Hess calls the cases and states the appearances.
Cases being heard today are 15CF393 and 16CF126.
ADA Hess states matter is set for a Re-sentencing hearing.
Court has received the PSI report and questions Parties.
Parties state they have received and reviewed the PSI. 
No corrections to be addressed.
ADA Hess addresses the Court.
Atty Drengler concurs with statements made by ADA Hess.
Court questions Mr. Johnston.
Mr. Johnston responds and requests to proceed today.

BY THE COURT:
Mr. Johnston has freely, voluntarily and intelligently decided to proceed today.

ADA Hess argues regarding sentencing.
Attt Drengler argues regarding sentencing.
Mr. Johnston addresses the Court.

BY THE COURT:
15CF393
Count 1:
Sentenced to Prison for 5 years - Concurrent with Count 2 & 16CF126
3 years initial confinement
2 years extended supervision
Jail credit of 721 days
**Conditions of Extended Supervision:
*No contact with Caleb Mansfield, J.G., Nickolus Slusser, Bancroft Quik Mart, Jacob Slusser, Carol Novack, Carl Novack, Joshua Hutkowski, Jeffrey Bindel, Mark Dexter, Country Sports and Paragon Farms or their residences or places of employment 
*Maintain absolute sobriety with regards to alcohol or illegal drugs. 
*Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription. 
*Obtain and maintain full-time employment until restitution is paid in full and then schooling or a combination of both equaling full-time
*Comply with any assessments, treatment, and programming as deemed appropriate by the Compass Assessment and the Department of Corrections.
*If the defendant becomes incarcerated, a portion of his prison wages shall go towards restitution (25%)
*Pay all court ordered financial obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge.
*Provide DNA sample if not already done so  
*Pay restitution to be paid first (pay in accordance to the restitution summary)
*Pay costs 
*Pay DNA Surcharge
*Not eligible for Challenge or Substance Abuse Program

Count 2:
Sentenced to Prison for 5 years - Concurrent to Count 1
3 years initial confinement
2 years extended supervision
**Conditions of Extended Supervision:
*Comply with conditions in count 1
*Pay costs 

Count 3:
Sentenced to 9 months of jail - Concurrent to Count 1 & 2     
**Conditions of Extended Supervision:
*Comply with conditions in count 1
*Pay costs

16CF126
Count 1:
Sentenced to Prison for 9 years - Concurrent with 15CF393
5 years initial confinement
4 years extended supervision
Jail credit of 541 days
**Conditions of Extended Supervision:
*Comply with conditions in 15CF393
*Pay costs
*Pay DNA Surcharge
*Eligible for the Substance Abuse Program after serving 3 years of initial confinement

Count 2:
Sentenced to Prison for 3.5 years - Concurrent with Count 1 and any other sentence 
1.5 years initial confinement
2 years extended supervision
**Conditions of Extended Supervision:
*Comply with conditions in 15CF393
*Pay costs

Count 3:
Sentenced to Prison for 3.5 years - Concurrent with count 1 & 2 and any other sentence
1.5 years initial confinement
2 years extended supervision
**Conditions of Extended Supervision:
*Comply with conditions in 15CF393
*Pay costs

Defendant James D. Johnston in court with attorney John H. Wallace. Defendant James D. Johnston in custody. Elizabeth R Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Cases heard today are 15CF393 and 16CF126.

3:26 p.m.  Court calls case.
Atty Constable states the appearances.
State has complied with victim notification on both cases.
State has multiple uncharged read-in's and provided to the Court along with Restitution Summaries.

Court and counsel have received their copies of the PSI.
Court questions if any correction need to be made on the record.
Atty Constable has a correction on Page 28 and states this on the record.
Atty Wallace does not have any corrections for the PSI.
Atty Constable states that no victims want to make any additional statements but would like the written statement be used.
Prosecutor argues regarding sentencing.
Attorney for Defendant argues regarding sentencing.
Defendant makes a statement prior to sentencing.

Sentencing hearing on June 23, 2016 at 02:30 pm.

Bond amended 3/30/16 to include that it now covers both files: 15CF393 & 16CF126.
No contact with Jessica Slusser or her residence or co-defendant, Caleb Mansfield.

Defendant James D. Johnston in court with attorney John H. Wallace. Defendant James D. Johnston in custody. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Both files heard: 15CF393, 16CF126

2:50 p.m.  Court calls the cases. 
Atty Constable files 4 Statements of Uncharged Read-ins and the Information in 16CF126. 
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

16CF126 INITIAL APPEARANCE/WAIVER OF PRELIMINARY HEARING/ARRAIGNMENT:
Attorney/Defendant received copy of criminal complaint.
Court informs defendant of charges and maximum penalties.
Attorney/Defendant waives reading of complaint.

Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions Attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial. 

State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information. 

15CF393 & 16CF126 PLEA HEARING: 
Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
15CF393 Counts 1, 2 & 3 - NO CONTEST
16CF126 Counts 1, 2 & 3 - NO CONTEST 

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Atty Wallace questions the defendant. 
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty 15CF393 Counts 1, 2 & 3, 16CF126 Counts 1, 2 & 3.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
The following uncharged files are read-in: 15PT2001, 15PT2022, 15PT2030, 15PT2028
Court orders a PSI. 

BY THE COURT:  Bond in 15CF393 now covers 16CF126 as well.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for June 23, 2016 at 02:30 pm.

Plea Hearing set for 03/30/16 - attempted, not known
